Package gw.api.exception

Class ExternalizableException

java.lang.Object
java.lang.Throwable
java.lang.Exception
java.lang.RuntimeException
gw.api.exception.ExternalizableException
All Implemented Interfaces:
HasErrorInfo, Serializable
Direct Known Subclasses:
SOAPException
public class ExternalizableException extends RuntimeException implements HasErrorInfo
This class represents an exception that is primarily intended for an external consumer (a webservice or servlet client) and provides failure information that the external consumer may find useful. For example an invalid parameter value might report the acceptable values. This class uses a builder pattern to simplify construction of the exception: throw new ExternalizableException().withDisplayKey("My.ResourceKey").with("Prop1",null).with("Prop2",null).withCause(t); This class is a thin wrapper around an ErrorInfo so (See ErrorInfo)

  • Constructor Details

    • ExternalizableException

      protected ExternalizableException()
      This constructor will construct an exception that has extractable error information. By default the http status is HttpServletResponse.SC_INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR. By default the soap fault is WsdlFault.FaultCode.Receiver. The information can be overridden or added via builder methods.

  • Method Details

    • withStatus

      public ExternalizableException withStatus(int status)
      This method will set the status before throwing. This status will be part of the rest response. By default the http status is HttpServletResponse.SC_INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR.
      Parameters:
      status - the status use HttpServletResponse.SC_ values for clarity
      Returns:
      this

    • withFaultCode

      public ExternalizableException withFaultCode(@NotNull gw.xml.ws.WsdlFault.FaultCode value)
      This method will set the soap fault (see WsdlFault.FaultCode) before throwing. This will be part of the soap fault message. By default this is Receiver.
      Parameters:
      value - the fault
      Returns:
      this

    • withRetryableInPeriod

      public ExternalizableException withRetryableInPeriod(String retryableInPeriod)
      This method will set the retry period before throwing. This should be an xml duration.

      The time interval is specified in the following form "PnYnMnDTnHnMnS" where:

      • P indicates the period (required)
      • nY indicates the number of years
      • nM indicates the number of months
      • nD indicates the number of days
      • T indicates the start of a time section (required if you are going to specify hours, minutes, or seconds)
      • nH indicates the number of hours
      • nM indicates the number of minutes
      • nS indicates the number of seconds
      Error info declares some useful constants: ErrorInfo.RETRY_NOW ErrorInfo.RETRY_IN_AN_HOUR ErrorInfo.RETRY_TOMORROW
      Parameters:
      retryableInPeriod - the retryable period.
      Returns:
      this

    • withCause

      public ExternalizableException withCause(@NotNull @NotNull Throwable cause)
      This method will capture the exception that caused this exception.
      Parameters:
      cause - the cause
      Returns:
      this

    • withDisplayKey

      public ExternalizableException withDisplayKey(@PropertyKey(resourceBundle="locale.display") @NotNull @PropertyKey(resourceBundle="locale.display") @NotNull String displayKey)
      This method will set the display key for this exception. Note that property values will be used as arguments to DisplayKey when creating the message string. Properties should be added in the order referenced by the display resource.
      Parameters:
      displayKey - the display key for this exception
      Returns:
      this

    • with

      public ExternalizableException with(@NotNull @NotNull String propName, Object value)
      This method will add a property, the property value is used as an argument when creating the message and as a property to the serialized error info.
      Parameters:
      propName - the name of the property
      value - the value of the property, note that some property types are directly usable (Date for example) others will have their toString method called to serialize
      Returns:
      this
